author: Stuart Mathieson
title: Warren Joyce will not return to Manchester United as club continue search for new reserve team boss
text:
Warren Joyce will not return to Manchester United as club continue search for new reserve team boss Joyce was sacked by Wigan last month but will not be returning to the Carrington set-up Share Joyce swapped United for Wigan last year - but only lasted 24 games (Photo: Gareth Copley) Share   
Warren Joyce will not be re-joining Manchester United as the club continue their search for a new reserve team boss. 
The Red Devils' former Under-23 manager left Old Trafford in November to take the top job at Wigan, but was sacked earlier this month, reports the Manchester Evening News . 
Academy director Nicky Butt was handed the job on a temporary basis, but the club will now not go back to Joyce, who managed only 24 matches at the Latics. 
Joyce oversaw a string of reserve titles during his time with the club and brought through players such as Marcus Rashford, Paul Pogba and Jesse Lingard to the senior side. Wigan sacked Joyce earlier this month (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
United's four-month search for Joyce's replacement has made progress with some candidates being interviewed for the job. 
However, Butt said in January that the Reds won't be rushed and want to make certain they get the right. 
“It's something we're looking at and something we've got to get right,” he said. 
“It's a very important age group to manage and look after. It's the last step into the first team or into different clubs to try to make a career. 
“It's important and we're going through the process of having interviews. We don't want to make it a rush job and get the wrong person in.” Joyce achieved much success at Carrington (Photo: Rex) 
Butt, however, doesn't want the job himself on a permanent basis having been the interim manager. 
“I am enjoying it but there's a bigger job and a bigger picture with the club to do, right from the Under-12s to the Under-23s, and it's something I'm keen to get started again.” 
United's 23s have only three matches left in their Premier League 2 Division One campaign but are facing a relegation as they stand in eight position in the 12-team league but are only three points off the bottom. 
Ex-players like Paul Scholes and Phil Neville, Butt's Class of '92 mates, were initially touted to be included among the candidates but the fact the search has gone on so long suggests United are ready to poach a new reserve boss from another club at the end of the season. Nicky Butt has taken the helm temporarily (Photo: Getty) 
Back in September Kieran McKenna was identified as the new Under 18s manager, as successor to Paul McGuinness who left last season, and was lured from Tottenham. 
Butt has been in charge a huge revamp of United academy since he was appointed to head up the operation in February 2016 and has been part of the interview and recruitment process for the Under 23 job. poll loading Will Nicky Butt graduate to be Manchester United boss one day? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
